Scheme 1 Catalytic oxidation of cyclohexanol with TBHP. Scheme 2 Proposed catalytic cycle for the oxidation of cyclohexanol with TBHP over Cr-13X. Fig. 1 XRD patterns of various transition-metal M-13X zeolite catalysts. Fig. 2 XRD patterns of various Cr3+-exchanged catalysts. Fig. 3 XRD patterns of Cr-13X catalysts with different Cr3+ contents. Fig. 4 SEM images of Cr-13X(2) catalyst (a) and parent 13X zeolite (b). Fig. 5 The oxidation of cyclohexanol with TBHP over various M-13X zeolites. (Reaction condition: cyclohexanol, 40mmol; TBHP, 10mmol; catalyst, 100mg; reaction temperature, 363K; reaction time, 10h.) Fig. 6 Effect of substrate/oxidant molar ratios (a, 0.2–0.5, and b, 1–5) on the oxidation of cyclohexanol over Cr-13X(2). (Reaction condition: catalyst, 100mg; reaction temperature, 363K; reaction time, 10h.) Fig. 7 Effect of the reaction temperature on the oxidation of cyclohexanol over Cr-13X(2). Highly efficient catalytic oxidation of cyclohexanol with TBHP over Cr-13X catalysts in a solvent-free system Kun Li Dan Zhou ⁎ Jiejie Deng Xinhuan Lu Qinghua Xia ⁎ Hubei Collaborative Innovation Center for Advanced Organic Chemical Materials, & Ministry-of-Education Key Laboratory for the Synthesis and Application of Organic Functional Molecules, Hubei University, Wuhan 430062, PR China Hubei Collaborative Innovation Center for Advanced Organic Chemical Materials, & Ministry-of-Education Key Laboratory for the Synthesis and Application of Organic Functional Molecules, Hubei University Wuhan 430062 PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Tel.: +86 27 50865387; fax: +86 27 88663043. Graphical abstract Simple, inexpensive, reusable, and highly efficient solid catalyst Cr-13X for the oxidation of cyclohexanol with TBHP into cyclohexanone in the absence of any solvent and additive. With respect to the consideration of environment and economy, simple, inexpensive, and reusable solid catalysts have been attracting much attention. In this work, a series of non-noble transition-metal ion-exchanged zeolite catalysts have been prepared and applied in the catalytic oxidation of cyclohexanol and other alcohols with tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) to aldehydes or ketones in the absence of any solvent and additive. Among various catalysts tested, Cr3+-exchanged 13X has exhibited the best activity with the highest efficiency of TBHP utilization, and been proven to be a recyclable heterogeneous catalyst for the oxidation of cyclohexanol with TBHP. The effects of the Cr loading, the reaction temperature, the reaction time, and the cyclohexanol/TBHP molar ratio have been investigated systematically. Furthermore, a feasible oxidation route is proposed. Keywords Ion-exchanged zeolite Cr-13X Solvent-free oxidation Cyclohexanol TBHP 1 Introduction The oxidation of alcohols into aldehydes and ketones is a fundamental and important transformation in organic synthesis because the products are important precursors for various chemicals [1–3]. Traditionally, inorganic oxidants, such as PCC, MnO2, Na2Cr2O7, NaClO4, and KMnO4, are used in the oxidation of alcohols, which lead to much quantity of toxic wastes and serious environmental problems. In recent decades, many efforts have been dedicated to the exploration of catalytic procedures using environmentally benign oxidants like tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) with characteristics of cheapness, cleanness, high oxygen availability, which is widely used in organic synthesis [4], and produces the sole by-product tert-butanol that can be easily separated from the product by evaporation. Due to these advantages, many catalytic systems that employ TBHP as stoichiometric oxidant have been developed for the oxidation of alcohols [5–12]. However, the usage of solvent in the oxidation system is normally necessary, inclusive of acetonitrile, benzaldehyde, toluene, tert-butyl alcohol, n-hexane, methanol, and so on. Thus, the pursuit of the catalytic oxidation system without any solvent is desired. On the other hand, the efficient utilization of TBHP is particularly important for economic consideration. Due to high atom utilization, noble-metal-containing heterogeneous catalysts (Pt, Pd, Au, Ru, Se, etc.) have attracted tremendous interests in the oxidation of alcohols to corresponding aldehydes and ketones [1,13–19]. Transition-metal complex catalysts have been extensively studied for the oxidation of alcohols to aldehydes and ketones [20–23], but the complicated preparation procedure of catalysts with the consumption of large amount of organic solvents is a big disadvantage. Compared to other heterogeneous catalyst, molecular sieve materials have been a subject of growing interests in the oxidation of alcohols, which exhibit superior catalytic performance because of their open framework structures and high surface areas [9,24,25]. The oxidation of cyclohexanol with TBHP to cyclohexanone, applied as an important intermediate in the manufacturing of nylon, and plasticizer and food additive, has been conducted over encapsulated copper(II) complexes/Y heterogeneous catalysts, in which, TBHP in di-tert-buthylperoxide was used as the oxidant [9]. Lounis et al. reported the catalytic oxidation of functionalized alcohols and benzylic methylene groups with TBHP over Cr3+-exchanged ZSM-5, however, in which the solvent toluene must be added [25]. Herein, we first report the solvent-free oxidation of cyclohexanol and other alcohols with TBHP over transition metal (Mn, Zn, Fe, Co, Ni, Ru, V, Cu, and Cr) ions exchanged zeolites or molecular sieves prepared by a simple ion-exchange route. Among various zeolite catalysts, Cr3+-containing 13X (Cr-13X) zeolite exhibited the best catalytic activity in the solvent-free oxidation of cyclohexanol with TBHP with high utilization efficiency. Furthermore, other alcohols were effectively oxidized to aldehydes or ketones over Cr-13X. Recycling studies proved the recyclability of Cr-13X as a heterogeneous catalyst under mild conditions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Zeolites and molecular sieves (13X, Beta, USY, ZSM-5, SAPO-5, SAPO-34) were commercial products. Various alcohols underwent re-distillation treatment prior to use, inclusive of cyclohexanol (>99%), cyclopentanol (>99%), benzylalcohol (>99%), 4-hydroxybenzyl alcohol (>99%), and 4-methoxybenzyl alcohol (>99%). All other reagents were used as received without further purification, including manganese nitrate (>99%, Mn(NO3)2·6H2O), zinc nitrate (>99%, Zn(NO3)2·6H2O), ferric nitrate (>98.5%, Fe(NO3)3·9H2O), cobalt (II) nitrate (>99%, Co(NO3)2·6H2O), nickelous nitrate (>98%, Ni(NO3)2·6H2O), copper (II) nitrate (>99%, Cu(NO3)2·3H2O), ruthenium (III) chloride (>99%, RuCl3·9H2O), vanadium pentoxide (V2O5, obtained by the calcination of ammonium metavanadate at 723K for 3h), chromic (III) nitrate (>99%, Cr(NO3)3·9H2O), chromic (III) acetate (>99%, Cr(OAc)3), chromium (III) chloride (>99%, CrCl3), and aqueous tert-butyl hydroperoxide (65%, TBHP). 2.2 Preparation of catalysts Transition metal ions (Mn2+, Zn2+, Fe3+, Co2+, Ni2+, Ru3+, V5+, Cu2+, Cr3+) were introduced into zeolites by a simple ion-exchange method as reported in the literature [26]. In a typical run, 3.0g of zeolite solid powder was treated with 200ml of Cr3+ aqueous solution (8.7mmol/L) under continuous stirring at 363K overnight. The solid powder was recovered by filtration, washed several times with hot distilled water until no acidic residue was detected, and followed by drying at 373K for 8h. Other transition metal ions exchanged zeolite catalysts were prepared through the same procedure stated above. In addition, Cr-13X catalysts with different Cr3+ contents had been prepared through the ion-exchange of zeolite with Cr3+ aqueous solution with different Cr3+ concentration (8.7, 17.3, 26.0, and 34.6mmol/L), and named as Cr-13X(1), Cr-13X(2), Cr-13X(3), and Cr-13X(4), respectively. 2.3 Characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of samples were recorded on a Rigaku D/MAX-IIIC diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ =1.54184Å) operating at 30kV and 25mA. Transition metal contents in catalysts were analyzed on a Shimadzu XRF-1800 spectrometer. The morphology and size of crystals were imaged on a JEOL JSM-6510A scanning electron microscope (SEM). The BET specific surface area was calculated using the BET equation in the range of relative pressures (p/p 0) between 0.05 and 0.25. 2.4 Oxidation of cyclohexanol The catalytic oxidation of cyclohexanol (Scheme 1 ) was carried out in a 25-mL single-necked round-bottom glass flask equipped with a cryogenic-liquid condenser under atmospheric pressure. In a typical run, 40.0mmol of cyclohexanol, 10.0mmol of TBHP, and 100mg of the catalyst were added to the reactor, and the mixture was stirred vigorously by a magnetic stirrer and heated in a preheated water bath. After the completion of the reaction, the liquid products were separated by centrifugation and analyzed by a gas chromatograph equipped with a capillary column (SE-30, 30m×0.25mm×0.25μm) and an FID detector, in which chlorobenzene was used as an internal standard to quantify all the components, and the solid catalyst was separated by filtration and washed thoroughly with acetone and ethanol, and dried at 373K overnight for the next use. The cyclohexanol conversion, cyclohexanone selectivity, TBHP conversion and TBHP efficiency were calculated by using Eqs. (1)–(4). (1) Cyclohexanol conversion ( mol % ) = moles of cyclohexanol reacted total moles of cyclohexanol × 100 (2) Cyclohexanone selectivity ( % ) = moles of cyclohexanone formed moles of cyclohexanol reacted × 100 (3) TBHP conversion ( mol % ) = moles of TBHP reacted total moles of TBHP × 100 (4) TBHP efficiency ( % ) = moles of TBHP for the oxidation of cyclohexanol to cyclohexanone moles of TBHP reacted × 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of various transition-metal ion-exchanged 13X zeolite catalysts and the parent Na-13X zeolite. It is obvious that various transition-metal ions-exchanged 13X catalysts still maintained the diffraction characteristics of crystalline 13X zeolite framework. Fig. 2 shows the XRD patterns of various Cr3+-exchanged aluminosilicate zeolites (Beta, USY, ZSM-5, and 13X) and silicoaluminophosphate (SAPO-5 and SAPO-34). It was observed that there was no obvious change in the crystalline structure of zeolites that had undergone ion-exchange treatment, as compared to those parent zeolites. Fig. 3 shows the XRD patterns of Cr-13X catalysts with different Cr3+ contents. With the increase of the Cr3+ concentration of the solution from 8.7mmol/L to 17.3, 26.0, and 34.6mmol/L, the XRD intensity of thus-recovered catalysts Cr-13X(1), Cr-13X(2), Cr-13X(3), and Cr-13X(4) decreased gradually, probably due to the removal of partial Al species from the framework of zeolite during ion-exchange process in acidic solution, which was consistent with the XRF analysis as listed in Table 1 , which shows a gradual decrease of the Si/Al molar ratios from Cr-13X(1) to Cr-13X(4). The detailed physicochemical characterizations of Cr-zeolite catalysts are shown in Table 1. The scanning electron micrographs of Cr-13X(2) catalyst and 13X are shown in Fig. 4 , indicating that the morphologies and particle sizes of catalysts that have undergone the ion-exchange treatment are still similar to those of the parent zeolite. 3.2 The oxidation of cyclohexanol over various M-13X catalysts Various transition-metal ion-exchanged M-13X zeolite catalysts were prepared and applied in the catalytic oxidation of cyclohexanol with TBHP. The reaction results were demonstrated in Fig. 5 . Under identical experimental conditions (cyclohexanol/TBHP molar ratio=4, maximal theoretic conversion of cyclohexanol=25mol%), various M-13X showed different catalytic properties in the oxidation of cyclohexanol. Mn-13X can merely convert 4.1mol% of cyclohexanol to cyclohexanone with TBHP efficiency of 16.5%. Other M-13X zeolites (M=Zn/Fe/Co/Ni/Ru/V/Cu) may convert 10–20mol% of cyclohexanol, along with TBHP efficiency in the range of 45∼80%. In contrast, Cr-13X(2) presented excellent catalytic activity (conversion of 24.7mol%) and utilization efficiency of TBHP (98.9%), remarkably higher than those over other catalysts. It's noteworthy that the efficient utilization of TBHP in the oxidation reaction of alcohols is especially important with respect to the economic and commercial consideration. All catalysts can achieve 100% selectivity of cyclohexanone under mild reaction conditions. Based on the above results, chromium (Cr3+) is considered to be an effective component for the catalytic oxidation of cyclohexanol with TBHP. 3.3 The oxidation of cyclohexanol over various Cr3+-exchanged catalysts According to the above results, a series of Cr3+-exchanged aluminosilicate and silicoaluminophosphate (SAPO) molecular sieves had been prepared and applied in the oxidation of cyclohexanol (Table 2 ). At 363K, the selectivity of cyclohexanone always maintained at the level of 100% over all Cr3+-exchanged molecular sieve catalysts. All Cr3+-exchanged zeolites showed higher catalytic oxidation ability than the corresponding parent zeolites. Cr-13X(2) acted as the best catalyst for the oxidation reaction of cyclohexanol, with 100mol% conversion and 98.9% utilization efficiency of TBHP. Therefore, the oxidation of cyclohexanol with TBHP under different reaction conditions was performed over Cr-13X(2) in the following studies. 3.4 Effect of the cyclohexanol/TBHP molar ratios on the oxidation of cyclohexanol The effect of substrate/oxidant molar ratios on the oxidation of cyclohexanol was systematically studied and depicted in Fig. 6 . When the molar ratio of cyclohexanol/TBHP was less than 1.0 (Fig. 6a), with the increase of the molar ratio from 0.2 to 0.5, the cyclohexanone selectivity showed a slight increase from 90.1 to 98%, while the conversion of cyclohexanol decreased sharply from 96 to 65mol%, companied with the TBHP efficiency lower than 31.9%. When the molar ratio of cyclohexanol/TBHP was in the range of 1.0–5.0, the cyclohexanone selectivity could be maintained at 100%, and no over-oxidized products were detected from the liquid mixture. With the increase of the cyclohexanol/TBHP molar ratio from 1.0 to 4.0, the cyclohexanol conversion decreased correspondingly from 41.8 to 24.7mol%, but the TBHP efficiency increased from 40.9 to 98.9%. However, when the cyclohexanol/TBHP molar ratio continued to increase from 4.0 to 5.0, the TBHP efficiency showed a reduction from 98.9 to 92.1%. Therefore, the oxidation of cyclohexanol was conducted at the substrate/oxidant molar ratio of 4 in the other studies. Table 3 compares the oxidation of cyclohexanol with TBHP over various heterogeneous catalysts reported in the literature and this work. As observed from the results, the complexes of Co, Mn, and Cu, [Co(bpy)2]2+/bentonite [7], [Mn(bpy)2]2+/HMS [8], [Cu((C6H5)2[13]1,4-dieneN2O2)]2+-NaY [9], [Cu2(μ-O2CC6H5)4(4-DMAP)2] [10] and vanadium-containing catalysts [5,6] have shown catalytic activities. However, the above catalytic systems contain three main defects, i.e. the complicated preparation procedure of complex catalysts, quite low concentration of substrate, and the usage of much amount of organic solvents. Thus, our present solvent-free oxidation system of cyclohexanol with TBHP over Cr-13X is much advantageous. 3.5 Effect of temperature, time and Cr loading on the oxidation of cyclohexanol over Cr-13X The effect of reaction temperature on the oxidation of cyclohexanol with TBHP over Cr-13X(2) was studied and the result was illustrated in Fig. 7 . With increasing the reaction temperature from 343 to 363K, the cyclohexanol conversion was increased from 20.6 to 24.7mol%, accompanied with the increase of TBHP efficiency from 86.7 to 98.9%. When the temperature was increased from 363 to 383K, both the cyclohexanol conversion and the TBHP efficiency were gradually decreased from 24.7 to 19.0mol% and from 98.9 to 76.2%, possibly attributed to thermal decomposition of TBHP at higher reaction temperatures. Fig. 8 shows the effect of reaction time on the oxidation of cyclohexanol with TBHP over Cr-13X(2). With the increase of reaction time from 2 to 10h, the cyclohexanol conversion showed a slight increase from 16.7 to 24.7mol%, with 100% of the cyclohexanone selectivity. Similarly, the TBHP efficiency presented an increase trend from 77 to 98.9% with prolonging the time from 2 to 10h. The loading amount of Cr3+ in 13X had an important role in the oxidation of cyclohexanol, as listed in Table 4 . It was found that the catalyst Cr-13X(2) with 4.20wt% of chromium exhibited the best catalytic activity, with 24.7mol% of cyclohexanol conversion and 98.9% of TBHP efficiency. Cr-13X(4) with 3.61wt% of chromium can only convert 17.6mol% of cyclohexanol and achieve 76.6% of TBHP efficiency. 3.6 Recycling studies The recycling experiments of Cr-13X(2) catalysts for the oxidation of cyclohexanol were conducted. As observed from Fig. 9 , the conversion of cyclohexanol was still maintained at a high level of >21mol%, even if the catalyst had been used five times, and all the reactions maintained almost a constant level of 100% selectivity, and a high TBHP efficiency of >86%. The XRF results of catalysts used five times were listed in supporting information Table S2. Compared with the fresh Cr-13X(2), the reused catalysts showed an obvious decrease in the Cr contents, implying the occurrence of leaching of chromium, mainly due to free Cr3+ ions trapped in the pores of the fresh one. However, the Cr contents of recycled four catalysts maintained a more or less constant, indicative of the stability of this catalyst. This study further revealed the heterogeneity of catalysis occurred over Cr-13X(2). The XRD patterns and SEM images are shown in the supporting information Figs. S1 and S2, respectively. Clearly, the morphology and particle size of Cr-13X(2) do not show any obvious change with recycling; however, the intensity of diffraction peaks of Cr-13X(2) has shown a gradual reduction for the latter two recycles. To further verify the activity of the catalyst, we did a series of control experiments, as shown in Table S1. When there was no catalyst for this reaction, only 30.1mol% of TBHP conversion and 57.2% of TBHP efficiency were obtained. Once Cr-13X(2) was added, 100mol% of TBHP conversion and 98.9% of TBHP efficiency can be achieved. This shows the significance of the catalyst in promoting this reaction. By comparing Entries 2 and 4 we can see that TBHP was main oxygen source for the oxidation of cyclohexanol, and air could oxidize only 2.1mol% of cyclohexanol. By comparing Entries 3 and 4, we can know that the catalyst Cr-13X(2) could not catalytically decompose all of TBHP alone; once cyclohexanol and TBHP were added simultaneously, 100mol% of TBHP conversion and 98.9% of TBHP efficiency were achieved within 10h. Based on the above observations and results, one catalytic reaction route for the oxidation of cyclohexanol with TBHP over Cr-13X is proposed in Scheme 2 . Under reaction conditions, Cr3+-zeolite, TBHP and cyclohexanol can initially form pentacyclic transition-state intermediates, and then dehydrate to produce cyclohexanone. 3.7 Oxidation of other alcohols over Cr-13X The catalytic oxidation of other alcohols (like cyclopentanol, benzylalcohol, 4-hydroxybenzyl alcohol, 4-methoxybenzyl alcohol, n-pentanol, 1-butanol, and isobutanol) over Cr-13X(2) was described in Table 5 . It was observed that Cr-13X(2) showed good catalytic oxidation activity for cyclic alcohols and aromatic ones, such as cyclopentanol, cyclohexanol, benzylalcohol, 4-hydroxybenzyl alcohol, and 4-methoxybenzyl alcohol. However, Cr-13X(2) did not exhibit any catalytic oxidation ability for acyclic alcohols, such as n-pentanol, 1-butanol, and isobutanol. Considering the proposed reaction route illustrated in Scheme 2, the probable reasoning can be ascribed to the negative effect of acyclic alcohol molecules on the formation of stable pentacyclic transition-state intermediates, and subsequent dehydration due to electron effects. 4 Conclusions Simple, inexpensive, and reusable solid catalyst, ion-exchanged M-zeolites were prepared and used as the catalysts for the oxidation of cyclohexanol into cyclohexanone with tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) as the oxidant under solvent-free conditions. At 363K, Cr-13X exhibited outstandingly catalytic performance with a complete conversion of TBHP and 98.9% of TBHP efficiency, in which the turnover number was 98.8mol/molcat with 100% of selectivity to cyclohexanone at the molar ratio of 4 (cyclohexanol):1 (TBHP) under ambient pressure. Also, this catalyst showed good catalytic activity for the oxidation of other cyclic alcohols and aromatic ones. A feasible reaction route is proposed, in which the formation of stable pentacyclic transition-state intermediates is vital for the completion of oxidation reaction.
